title: Raytheon Names Neil Mitchill as Chief Financial Officer
summary: Mr. Mitchill succeeds Anthony O'Brien, who is stepping down as finance chief of the aerospace supplier. Raytheon Technologies Corp. named Neil Mitchill as chief financial officer, succeeding former CFO Anthony O'Brien, who left the company.

title: Norwegian Cruise Line, Netflix, Amazon.com: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd.

title: Startup Behind AstraZeneca Covid-19 Vaccine Files for U.S. IPO
summary: U.K.-based Vaccitech, spun out of the University of Oxford in 2016, has been aiming for valuation of around $700 million. LONDON-The biotech startup behind the Covid-19 vaccine jointly developed by AstraZeneca PLC and the University of Oxford filed Friday with U.S. regulators for a public share offering.

title: Biden Commissions the Supreme Court
summary: His panel on court-packing tilts sharply to the legal and political left.. President Biden on Friday announced his Presidential Commission on the Supreme Court, which is better understood as the commission on packing the Supreme Court. The White House is trying to make this seem like routine political business, but don't be fooled.

title: Biden's Surge at the Southern Border
summary: The latest migrant numbers show much more than a seasonal increase.. The White House has tried to pass off the migrant surge at the U.S.-Mexico border as nothing more than a routine seasonal sojourn. "It happens every year," President Biden said in a news conference last month. New York Rep. Ritchie Torres called the crisis "more of a cyclical occurrence than a unique consequence of the Biden Administration policy."

title: Amazon Workers Reject a Union
summary: Big Labor pulled out all the stops to organize an Alabama warehouse.. For five months the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union pitched itself as a savior to employees at an Amazon warehouse in Alabama, but the workers have now said no thanks. By a preliminary vote of 71% to 29% tallied Thursday and Friday, the employees turned down the chance to unionize and declined to join the left's aggressive campaign against employers.

title: A State Lockdown Accounting
summary: With rare exceptions, the states that shut down the longest suffered the most economic harm.. If the 2008 financial panic became the Great Recession, let's call the last year the Great Lockdown. As the U.S. economy reopens more fully, comparative data is emerging about the 50 states that illuminate how much of the economic harm was self-inflicted.

title: Know Thyself, but Don't Think There's an App for That
summary: Your phone may be smart when it comes to your biometrics, but being thoughtful is up to you.. 'Know thyself" is the philosopher's perennial suggestion, the beginning and end of wisdom. It seems simple, but we regularly fail to do it, preferring instead to devote ourselves to goods that are fleeting and ultimately empty-power, money, pleasure, fame. If we understood ourselves better, and assessed ourselves frankly, we might live more fulfilling lives.

title: 'The Agitators' Review: Disturbers of the Peace
summary: How Harriet Tubman, Martha Wright and Frances Seward challenged a nation's conscience.. In the turbulent decades leading up to the Civil War, it could be said that the moral center of the nation rested in the Finger Lakes region of central New York state. The district was a hot spot of abolitionism and the fledgling women-rights movement.

title: Must the Justices Create a Trustworthy Press?
summary: Why not just hire smart people and ask them (or free them) to do honest reporting?. No writ exists in the Constitution for journalism's holy of holies, the 1964 Times v. Sullivan Supreme Court ruling that allows us falsely to defame public figures as long as we do so without "actual malice." Such is a longstanding argument given new currency by veteran federal appeals judge Laurence Silberman in a dissenting opinion already covered repeatedly in these pages.

title: The EU Plays Politics With Northern Ireland
summary: A Brexit dispute threatens to upend the Good Friday Agreement I worked hard to finish 23 years ago.. The nationalist Catholic politician John Hume and I completed what became known as the Good Friday Agreement 23 years ago Saturday. It was designed to end the 35 years of violence that had cost thousands of lives in Northern Ireland and beyond, and to deal with the sectarian divisions that had allowed terrorism to fester. Today tensions are returning, as the agreement is in danger from a dispute over Brexit.

title: Notable & Quotable: A Fridge Full of Infrastructure
summary: Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand's redefinition of the word meets ridicule.. Tamar Lapin writing in the New York Post, April 7:

title: Covid Provides a Rare Chance to Transform Public Education
summary: In post-Katrina New Orleans, Louisiana built a system that serves the needs of students, not adults.. The Covid-19 pandemic has brought into focus a stark choice: Will we respond to the enormous disruption of schools by rethinking education, or will we double down on an outdated industrial-age system created to prepare kids for the last century?

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Our celebration of seasonal books on topics like nature, gardening, food and baseball-plus David Hockney in France, Richard Thompson's musical memoir, 'The Agitators' and more..

title: America's Oldest Asian Ally, Overlooked
summary: The Biden administration is favoring Singapore and Vietnam over Thailand, a treaty partner since 1833.. President Biden has promised to work closely with allies and partners around the world. But he seems to be overlooking Asia's U.S. ally of longest standing, Thailand. Mr. Biden's Interim National Security Strategic Guidance omitted Thailand from its list of friends and allies in the Indo-Pacific.

title: Aramco Strikes $12.4 Billion Oil Pipeline Deal With EIG-Led Group
summary: Deal comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to diversify its economy and attract foreign investors. Saudi Arabia's energy giant said it struck a $12.4 billion deal to sell a 49% stake in a newly formed oil pipeline business to an international consortium led by U.S. investment firm EIG Global Energy Partners.

title: 'The Glitter in the Green' Review: Blink and You'll Miss Them
summary: The smallest avians have always captured imaginations-sometimes to their own detriment.. I can't recall when I saw my first hummingbird, but I clearly remember my son's first sighting. He was 6, on the porch swing of his great-grandmother's lakeside cottage in the Adirondacks. "Wow," he said. "That's an awfully big fly."

title: 'The Horde' Review: Path of Khans
summary: At its height, the empire of Chinggis Khan drew strength from flexibility.. The Mongols have been ill-served by history, the victims of an unfortunate mixture of prejudice and perplexity. In popular memory Chinggis Khan exists chiefly in relation to the European and Chinese civilizations he threatened, and the rhythms and contours of steppe life are incomprehensible. Reflecting on "The Historian's Craft" (1949), Marc Bloch decried his peers' tendency "to assign an arbitrarily chosen and strictly pendulum-like rhythm to realities to which such regularity is entirely alien. It is an impossible task. Naturally, we do very badly at it. We must look for something better."

title: White House Border Coordinator Roberta Jacobson to Step Down at End of Month
summary: Departure comes as record number of unaccompanied minors crossed border illegally in March. Roberta Jacobson, the White House's border coordinator, will step down at the end of the month, national security adviser Jake Sullivan said in a statement Friday.

title: 'The God Equation' Review: One String Theory to Rule Them All
summary: What is the universe made of? Physicists have answers but no unified theory explaining everything.. What's God got to do with it? Given that the majority of physicists are agnostics at best, I have always found it puzzling that my community is so obsessed with God's mind, whether or not God plays dice, the God particle and seeing God-and now with Michio Kaku's "The God Equation." Title notwithstanding, this is an excellent book written by a masterful science communicator elaborating on a subject that is his research home turf-superstring theory. The prolific author of multiple popular science books, Mr. Kaku is a futurist, broadcaster and professor of theoretical physics at the City University of New York. He is also the host of the wildly successful and popular weekly radio program Science Fantastic. If there is anyone who can demystify the esoteric mathematics and physics of string theory, it is he. And in this wonderful little book, that is precisely what he does-explain in clear and simple terms the conceptual breakthroughs, the blind alleys and the unanswered questions-in the search for a grand unified theory of everything. Most of all, what I like best is that he remains open to the possibility that there may ultimately not be a single unifying theory after all, encoded into a single tidy equation.

title: 'A Short History of Humanity' Review: Lost Cousins
summary: Archaeogenetics has changed our picture of how ancient Homo sapiens spread-and who they met.. In the mid-20th century, the discovery that the carbon-14 isotope decays at a fixed rate unleashed the "radiocarbon revolution"-by measuring how much the carbon in material had decayed, an estimate could be made as to its age. Organic matter was now datable, as long as it had been part of a living organism in the last 50,000 years or so, and the study of prehistory was changed forever. Radiocarbon dating remains a basic tool of archaeology, and we are now living through an even greater revolution, what the scientist Johannes Krause and journalist Thomas Trappe call, in their bracing summary of what we have learned so far, "archaeogenetics"-the study of ancient DNA.

title: 'Waves Across the South' Review: New Kingdoms
summary: While crowned heads were losing their power in Europe, unrest elsewhere inaugurated monarchies.. In late 1805, Napoleon Bonaparte scored his famous victory over the Austrian and Russian armies on the wintertime battlefield of Austerlitz. At almost the same time half a world away, courtiers in the Sri Lankan kingdom of Kandy were celebrating their recent triumph over Anglo-Indian forces with an epic poem, the "Ingrisi Hatana" ("English Battle"), set down on palm leaves.

title: Amazon Workers in Alabama Vote Against Unionizing
summary: About 71% of Bessemer, Ala., warehouse employees who cast ballots opposed joining Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Amazon.com Inc. employees in Alabama voted not to unionize, handing the tech giant a victory in its biggest battle yet against labor-organizing efforts that fueled national debate over working conditions at one of the nation's largest employers.

title: 'Valcour' Review: The Guns of Lake Champlain
summary: A ship raised from the depths helps tell the story of a pivotal naval battle in the War of Independence.. Among the most striking exhibits at the National Museum of American History in Washington is the well-preserved Revolutionary War gunboat Philadelphia. In 1935, the sturdy vessel was raised from the depths of Lake Champlain, where she had lain undisturbed since being sunk by British gunfire on Oct. 11, 1776. Remarkably, one of the vessel's three guns was still loaded, and the 24-pound iron cannon ball that sent her to the bottom remained lodged in her hull.

title: Amazon's Alabama Union Vote: Here's What Happens Next
summary: Alabama warehouse workers side against unionization, a victory for tech giant in efforts to limit reach of labor organizing. Amazon.com Inc. employees at an Alabama warehouse voted not to unionize, after the effort to organize workers at the tech giant garnered national attention.

title: Medical Examiner Says Floyd's Heart Couldn't Handle Restraint
summary: Andrew Baker's testimony differs from previous medical experts who said Mr. Floyd died from asphyxia. George Floyd died because the police officers restraining him put more strain on his heart than it could handle, according to the chief medical examiner who conducted his autopsy in testimony Friday in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin.

title: Charter Hit With $19 Million Judgment for Windstream Bankruptcy Mailers
summary: The legal fight highlights the ways companies can try to capitalize when a competitor files for bankruptcy, and the perils that can invite. Cable operator Charter Communications Inc. told consumers to say goodbye to competitor Windstream Holdings Inc. when it filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy in 2019. That farewell message could be costly following a bankruptcy judge's ruling Thursday.

title: Celebrating and Satirizing New York's Aesthetes
summary: Florine Stettheimer's wry 1942 'The Cathedrals of Art' sends up the city's storied museums and the elites in their orbit.. She was the society insider and the artistic outlier. Florine Stettheimer (1871-1944) gathered about her the most fervent modernists of the 1920s and '30s-the likes of Marcel Duchamp, Alfred Stieglitz, Georgia O'Keeffe, Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein-whose intellectual and aesthetic energies shaped their era. As a painter she discarded all the prevailing definitions of modernism and painted just as she pleased. She invented her own visual language-purposefully naïve, sly, theatrical and allusive. It both celebrated and mocked her own rarefied milieu-upper-class bohemian life in Manhattan between the world wars.

title: Nancy Reagan and the Power of Intimacy
summary: Exercising an influence unlike any first lady before or since, she guided her husband's rise to power and secured his legacy.. First lady is a role that comes with no mandate and no job description. But there is one thing that many of them have learned the hard way: When the word "powerful" is used about a president's spouse, it is rarely intended as a compliment.

title: BJ's Wholesale Club CEO and President Lee Delaney Dies at 49
summary: Retailer says executive died unexpectedly, as board names Bob Eddy as interim CEO. BJ's Wholesale Club Holdings Inc. said Friday that its chief executive and president, Lee Delaney, had died unexpectedly.

title: Dow, S&P 500 Rally to Fresh Records
summary: Stocks have surged this week, led by sharp gains among technology companies. The S&P 500 advanced Friday and extended its weekly winning streak to three, its longest since October.

title: Biden Seeks More Money for Education, Health in Spending Plan
summary: President would raise discretionary spending by 8.4% to $1.52 trillion with focus on Democratic priorities. WASHINGTON-President Biden is seeking more funding for education, healthcare, research and renewable energy next year in a $1.52 trillion spending plan reflecting his vision of an expansive federal government that tackles issues ranging from climate change to racial inequality.

title: How Many Jobs Will Be Lost to Biden 'Infrastructure'?
summary: A Wharton study says wages will fall.. Sometimes the president calls his next proposed spending blowout an "infrastructure" bill and sometimes he calls it a "jobs" program. The Biden plan may end up destroying plenty of both. A new analysis of the president's "American Jobs Plan" from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School finds that over the next decade the Biden scheme would reduce U.S. economic growth, capital stock, wages and hours worked. But there is something that the plan would increase-federal debt. In short, it's a disaster for U.S. investors, workers and taxpayers.

title: Vaccination Passports Are New Flashpoint in Pandemic
summary: With no federal mandate to require a single vaccination credential, the private sector and local governments are filling the gaps. Vaccine passports are emerging as the latest polarizing issue in the Covid-19 pandemic, as policy makers debate whether Americans should have proof of inoculation to return to work, travel or attend events.

title: Biden Orders Study of Supreme Court Changes
summary: New commission will study potential measures including expanding the number of justices. WASHINGTON-President Biden ordered a commission to study Supreme Court changes such as adding seats, an idea pushed by progressives in his party that faces strong opposition from congressional Republicans.

title: How Bob Dylan and a Bogart Movie Inspired Al Stewart's 'Year of the Cat'
summary: The singer talks about the influences behind the 1976 hit-and why it was almost called 'Horse of the Year'. Al Stewart's "Year of the Cat," released in the U.S. in late 1976, was catchy but enigmatic. Produced by Alan Parsons, the song about a mystical tryst in Morocco peaked at No. 8 on the Billboard pop chart and became a yacht-rock classic.

title: U.S. Defense Chief Plans Israel Meetings Amid Iran Tensions
summary: Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin also plans to meet military chiefs in Europe as part of trip. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin is meeting with top Israeli leaders this weekend, making him the highest-ranking Biden administration official to visit that nation amid tensions between the longtime allies over U.S. talks to revive the 2015 Iran nuclear deal and the restoration of aid to Palestinians.

title: Vol. 34, No. 3: 'Year to Date'
summary: Most Popular News. It seems obvious, but maybe not. "Year to date change" or the "up/down so far this year" needs to be calculated from the last close of the previous year (Dec. 31, 2020, in other words, for year-to-date calculations for 2021), not the first close of the new year. The end point of the previous year is the base.

title: What's in Biden's Budget Proposal
summary: The document is an opening step in the federal budgeting process. The Biden administration on Friday released a budget outline for fiscal year 2022 that highlights the president's policy priorities, calling for increases in spending on education, healthcare and renewable energy.

title: Catching Some Z's (Saturday Crossword, April 10)
The Journal Acrostic (Saturday, April 10)
President's Budget Request Includes Funds for Corporate Ownership Registry
summary: The request would add $64 million to the budget of Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. A discretionary budget request released by the Biden administration includes a sizable boost for a unit of the U.S. Treasury Department tasked with building a complex corporate ownership registry.

title: Michigan Governor Urges Pause in Youth Sports, Indoor Dining as Covid-19 Cases Surge Again
summary: Rise in infections is a major test of what happens during an outbreak in a partially vaccinated population. Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer urged high-school classes to go remote for two weeks and called for a halt to both youth sports and indoor dining, to combat a steep surge in Covid-19 cases in the state.

title: The Report That Shook Britain's Race Lobby
summary: A government commission finds the U.K. is no longer 'deliberately rigged' against minorities. Cue the outrage and racial attacks on its chairman, Tony Sewell.. If you're an American who worries that your country's influence is waning, you may not be heartened to learn that it isn't. After last year's killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, angry demonstrators in Britain, emulating Black Lives Matter protests in the U.S., took to city streets. Some committed acts of vandalism. In the port city of Bristol, a statue of a local 17th-century philanthropist was toppled because he also traded in slaves. In London's Parliament Square, the words "Was a Racist" were daubed on the plinth of Winston Churchill's statue.

title: Eight Exercises to Improve Your Golf Game
summary: These workouts target your short game, swing rotation, clubhead speed and dynamic posture. All golfers are looking for ways to improve their game. Some don't even involve picking up a club.

title: What It's Like to Retire in Alaska
summary: It was the last place I wanted to even visit. Then we moved there.. I love warm weather. Sunshine caressing my skin, evening walks wearing tank tops and shorts, bedroom windows open at night-so lovely and comfortable. For 30 years, I had lived in San Diego, which was never really hot enough for me. I had never been to Alaska, was not particularly interested in it, and was fairly sure that it would be the last of the 50 states I would visit.

title: Amazon's Labor Unrest May Show at the Margins
summary: Unionization would be a challenge given Amazon's distribution scale, but impact could be felt on margin expansion. Would unionization hamstring Amazon.com 's business? The answer isn't clear-cut.

title: Pfizer, BioNTech Asks FDA to Expand Use of Covid-19 Vaccine to Adolescents
summary: Regulators are expected to move quickly; adolescents could get the shot in several weeks if the FDA signs off. Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE asked U.S. health regulators to allow their Covid-19 vaccine to be given to adolescents, which could make the shots available to kids in the coming weeks.

title: EU Investigates Reports of Blood Clots in Recipients of J&J Vaccine
summary: Three cases have occurred in the U.S. vaccination campaign and one in clinical trials. The European Union's health agency is investigating a small number of reports of severe blood clots among people who have received the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine.

title: How Do You Count Wild Rhinos? Very Carefully. (And With Elephants)
summary: Resume Subscription. CHITWAN, Nepal-It's time for the rhino census.

title: Prince Philip's Death Marks New Chapter for Strained British Monarchy
summary: The royal family faces uncertainty over where the institution goes next. LONDON-The death of Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth's husband of 73 years, is emblematic of a generational shift in the royal family and Britain as a whole, and comes at an already unsettled time for the House of Windsor.

title: Rapper DMX Dies at 50
summary: Influential New York musician who revived grittier sound in hip-hop had been hospitalized following heart attack. DMX, an influential and commercially successful rapper known for his gruff, barking delivery has died at the age of 50.

title: Dollar Hits Rough Patch After Strong Start to 2021
summary: Investors don't expect the currency's weakness to last as the U.S. economy outpaces others. The dollar has slipped this month as the Federal Reserve stuck to its message that it won't raise interest rates soon despite forecasts that the U.S. economy will recover faster than its peers.

title: American Original Georgia O'Keeffe Goes to Spain
summary: A new exhibition in Madrid explores the power of a painter who 'needed to move to create.'. When the 20-year-old Georgia O'Keeffe burst onto the New York gallery scene in 1917, the American art world was under the sway of French Cubism. But O'Keeffe's abstract charcoal drawings presented a version of modernism that was radically individual; she later described herself as "working into my own unknown-no one to satisfy but myself." She didn't make her first trip to Europe until 1953, when she was 66 years old, a mature artist.

title: CEOs Discover Progressive Political Religion
summary: Whatever happened to the concept of CEOs focusing on the interests of their shareholders? How about arguing against raising the corporate tax rate for starters?. Regarding Gerard Baker's "The C-Suite Converts to the New Political Religion" (Free Expression, April 6): Mr. Baker offers a timely cautionary tale to the corporate acolytes of the woke. It's one thing if the principal corporate officer can, indeed, represent that he or she speaks as a controlling owner of the enterprise on matters of political or cultural importance, or can verify that the opinions rendered reflect the majority of the owners' will. However, such a privilege seems unwarranted when the officer is, in fact, what can be accurately termed a "hired hand."

title: New York's Past is a Draw, Worth Preserving
summary: Can you imagine if Robert Moses had been successful in building a highway through Greenwich Village?. Kenneth T. Jackson asks: "Does New York Still Want to Be the Capital of the World?" (Cross Country, April 3). Dynamic change characterizes the city, not preservation, he claims, and blames the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission for blocking a proposal to build a residential tower in the South Street Seaport Historic District. But it's a question of law. Is he suggesting that the agency shirk its charter-defined mandate? The property is a vacant lot, and has been since the district was designated in 1977. The LPC is legally bound to determine whether new construction is "appropriate," and by no yardstick does this proposal fit that description. What could be built if the site wasn't part of the district is irrelevant.

title: Move on From 'If It Bleeds, It Leads' With Covid-19
summary: Never mind that the hundred cases reported in Washington state are one-hundredth of 1% of the total 1.2 million who have been vaccinated there.. Regarding Nicole Saphier's "Dr. Fauci, Tear Off These Masks" (op-ed, April 3): The media's new favorite Covid story in the interest of keeping the drama alive is "breakthrough cases," those fully vaccinated who have contracted Covid. Never mind that the hundred cases reported in Washington state are one-hundredth of 1% of the total 1.2 million who have been vaccinated there and that, given the vaccine is 95%, not 100% effective, this is to be expected. Only eight of the hundred were hospitalized and only two died, both over 80 and already ill.

title: Bernie Sanders Has Been Very Consistent All Along
summary: The kibbutz on which the 22-year-old Mr. Sanders spent a few months in 1963, kibbutz Sha'ar Ha'amakim, was reportedly affiliated with the left-wing Marxist Mapam Party.. In his fine March 27 review of Gary Saul Morson and Morton Schapiro's "Minds Wide Shut," Michael S. Roth cites the authors' reference to Bernie Sanders's 1988 trip to the Soviet Union but adds that "they don't mention his time on a kibbutz, I suppose, because they are less threatened by that kind of socialism," implying that there was a discontinuity between Sen. Sanders's view of "socialism" in the Soviet Union and on the kibbutz.

title: Is Joe Biden Embarrassed by Delaware's Voting Law?
summary: Thanks to Karl Rove for exposing the ways many states "restrict" voter turnout with their restrictive election laws, including President Biden's home state of Delaware.. Thanks to Karl Rove for exposing the ways many states "restrict" voter turnout ("Biden's Election Reform Deception," op-ed, April 1) with their restrictive election laws, including President Biden's home state of Delaware. May I suggest Mr. Rove begin the political movement to boycott Delaware?

title: De Blasio's More Sinister Version of 'Stop and Frisk'
summary: Isn't this the liberal version of "stop and frisk"?. Regarding the March 24 Notable & Quotable citing Seth Barron of City Journal about New York Mayor Bill de Blasio: Isn't this the liberal version of "stop and frisk," which Mr. de Blasio was so vehemently against?

title: How Will the U.K. Hold a Royal Funeral During Covid-19?
summary: Resume Subscription. LONDON-The death of Prince Philip while the U.K. remains in the grip of Covid-19 poses a question: How do you hold a funeral befitting a prince during a pandemic?

title: J&J Covid Vaccine Deliveries to Drop Sharply Next Week
summary: States are projected to get 700,000 doses, down from 4.9 million the week before. Deliveries of Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine doses throughout the U.S. are expected to plunge by more than 80% next week, according to state officials and federal data, as J&J grapples with manufacturing challenges.

title: Photos: Prince Philip, a Royal Life
summary: Scenes from the Duke of Edinburgh's life with Queen Elizabeth.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Vacation Rentals That Deliver Serenity and Fuel Creativity
summary: A pandemic-weary urbanite rents a farmhouse in Vermont, just down the road from where novelist Rudyard Kipling built his own safe haven. Plus: Former homes of famous writers, from Jane Austen to John Steinbeck, available as holiday rentals. RUDYARD KIPLING arrived in Brattleboro, Vt., hassled, broke and looking for a little peace and quiet. The Japanese bank in which he had kept all his money had collapsed in the early stages of the Panic of 1893. His wife, Carrie, was pregnant with their first child. And while a famous writer at that point, he had no novel with the publisher that could lift their fortunes.

title: Facebook Algorithm Shows Gender Bias in Job Ads, Study Finds
summary: Researchers found the platform's algorithms promoted roles to certain users; company pledges to continue work in removing bias from recommendations. Facebook Inc. disproportionately shows certain types of job ads to men and women, researchers have found, calling into question the company's progress in rooting out bias in its algorithms.

title: Can AI Apps Help Your Golf Swing?
summary: I don't think they are as good as a human instructor. But they can be helpful. And they are a lot cheaper.. To date, PGA Tour pros have been far better able than amateurs to take advantage of the new wave of analytic golf data. It makes sense: Being pros, they and their swing coaches are looking for the smallest deviations from perfection. Many tour pros these days travel with personal $25,000 TrackMan radars and work with other high-tech gear back home.

title: English Pharmacy Worker Made Fisherman's Friend a Global Hit
summary: Doreen Lofthouse, who has died at 91, found markets abroad for a local cold remedy. Fisherman's Friend lozenges weren't an obvious candidate for global marketing.

title: Nation's Largest School Districts Aim to Reopen Fully in the Fall
summary: CDC director says schools should plan to open in the fall; many districts plan for in-person classes, but say remote options will remain.

title: Prince Philip, Queen Elizabeth II's Husband, Dies at 99
summary: Duke of Edinburgh's passing marks the start of a generational transition for Britain's royal family. LONDON-Prince Philip, a constant presence at the side of Queen Elizabeth II and the longest-serving consort to a monarch in British history, has died. He was 99.

title: Russia Warns of Full-Scale War in Eastern Ukraine, Blames Kyiv
summary: The buildup of Russian troops on the border and escalating rhetoric threaten to derail efforts to reach a peaceful settlement. MOSCOW-The recent deployment of Russian troops along Ukraine's border and Moscow's indication that it could intervene in the event of a full-scale war in eastern Ukraine are dimming hopes for a peaceful resolution of the conflict that has festered for seven years and cost thousands of lives.

title: The Real Lessons of the Cuban Missile Crisis
summary: Newly uncovered Soviet sources show that the 1962 confrontation could easily have spiraled into nuclear war-a useful warning as we face a new arms race today.. The world is at the start of a new, undeclared nuclear arms race. In August 2019, the U.S. and Russia officially abandoned the Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces Treaty signed by Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev in 1987, leaving the door open to the development of new missiles. China has 300 nuclear weapons and is expected to double its arsenal in the next decade. Last month, the U.K. raised the cap on its nuclear stockpile by more than 40%, the first projected increase since the end of the Cold War.

title: Why Wasn't Prince Philip a King?
summary: In British royalty, the title of king is bestowed by the line of succession-not marriage. Prince Philip performed a dizzying array of royal duties after marrying into the British royal family, visiting countries around the world as companion to Queen Elizabeth-but never as king.

title: A Digital Vault to Store Information for Your Heirs
summary: Online vaults can hold the location of your will, bank-account numbers, ongoing subscriptions, recipes-anything your heirs will find useful. A growing number of digital-vault providers are competing to help you organize and secure your financial and personal information while you're alive-and simplify things for your heirs after you're gone.

title: White House to Push Infrastructure Plan at Chip Meeting
summary: Ford, GM and Intel are among companies slated to meet with administration officials on Monday.

title: Breonna Taylor Aftermath: Kentucky Law Limits No-Knock Warrants
summary: Warrants must be executed between 6 a.m. and 10 p.m., and officers are required to take more steps to obtain them. LOUISVILLE, Ky.-Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear signed a law Friday that places a partial ban on no-knock warrants after months of demonstrations set off by the fatal shooting of Breonna Taylor in her home during a botched police raid.

title: 'Finding Freedom' Review: Lost and Found
summary: After a childhood in her father's diner, Erin French opened a hard-won (and sought-after) restaurant of her own.. Every year thousands of people enter a lottery hoping for a table at the Lost Kitchen, a 40-seat restaurant in the remote town of Freedom, Maine, population 719. It's booked up a year in advance, the customers chosen by lottery each spring from around 20,000 hopefuls who mail in postcards requesting a table.

title: Ten Signs Things Might Be Getting Back to Normal
summary: Resume Subscription. There's no question: We're not out of the woods yet. But parts of pre-pandemic life are returning, from Hollywood movie openings to Major League Baseball games.

title: The False Promise of Quick-Fix Psychology
summary: Power posing, grit and other trendy concepts are scientifically unproven but have become enormously popular by offering simple solutions to deeply rooted social problems.. It would be hard to find a scientific field that has enjoyed as much mainstream success in the 21st century as social psychology. Social psychologists dominate the TED Talk stage, rack up impressive contracts as consultants to schools and companies, and write book after bestselling book. Their most viral ideas promise to solve some of society's most pressing problems, often in slickly counterintuitive ways.

title: 'Spring Cannot Be Cancelled' Review: Painting Out of the Pandemic
summary: Immersing himself in a bucolic farm setting, David Hockney finds inspired relief from lockdown.. The painter David Hockney and the critic Martin Gayford have been friends for 25 years. Their friendship, Mr. Gayford writes, has largely been "conducted at a distance, by email, phone calls, an occasional parcel, and a steady stream of pictures that arrive almost daily in my inbox." When they meet again "after months or even years," their conversation resumes "as if there had been no interruption," except for "a constant, almost imperceptible, shift in perspective."

title: 'Beeswing' Review: The Ditty and the Dirge
summary: Richard Thompson's performances and writing balance humor with a deep understanding of life's tragic side.. Now that Bruce, Elton, Keith, Neil-first names will do-have met the various deadlines for their autobiographies, it's time for the headliners of smaller rooms to offer their perspective. "Give me a folk club with thirty people who treat you as nothing special," says songwriter Richard Thompson in his new memoir, "Beeswing," where you are "an equal with the audience, no more." The view is very different at Madison Square Garden.

title: Don't Be Fooled by the Market's Newest Magic Trick

title: Fiction: 'Abundance' Review
summary: A father walks an economic tightrope in Jakob Guanzon's debut novel.. Wall Street bond-trader-turned-photojournalist Chris Arnade has explained that to begin to get a sense of the lives of poor people in America it is crucial to grasp the importance of two places: McDonald's and Walmart. For those who belong to what Mr. Arnade calls the country's "back row," these serve as improvised community centers-warm, well-lighted spaces with clean bathrooms (and in Walmart's case, free overnight parking) where they can connect with others without spending much money.

title: 'Miracles on the Hardwood' Review: Faith, Hoops and Charity
summary: From scruffy gym floors to massive arenas, Catholic-school basketball is a religion of its own.. When Gonzaga University's Jalen Suggs scored his buzzer-beating bank shot in the NCAA's Final Four last week, fans of Catholic college basketball cheered: The team from the Jesuit school had created an indelible moment in one of America's great pastimes. And although Suggs and the Zags went on to suffer a defeat in the championship game against Baylor on Monday night, they added to the lore of Catholic cagers.

title: 'The Letters of Robert Frost' Review: Poetry and Pressure
summary: The poet grapples with success and personal tragedy in correspondence from the 1930s.. 'Once in a while I meet someone who has read me. It did him good. I mean it served him right." A way of identifying these terse sentences would be to name some poets of the modern era who could not have written them: W.B. Yeats and T.S. Eliot will do for starters, helping to set off the distinctive voice of Robert Frost. Had the quotation ended with "It did him good," one might assume a feisty, self-justifying voice behind it; but when that voice adds "I mean it served him right," we're less certain just what to call it. "Playful" would be a place to start-and a fair way to characterize most of the letters Frost wrote in his life, now displayed in the third of this five-volume edition of his correspondence, masterfully edited within an inch of its life by Mark Richardson and three fellow scholars. The seven years represented, 1929-36, weigh in at 800 pages and would surely, if Frost had seen them, have made him wonder whether it had indeed served him right.

title: Why Ron DeSantis's 2024 Stock Is Rising

title: Mysteries: 'Mother May I' Review
summary: A kidnapper's instructions lead a woman down a deadly path in Joshilyn Jackson's thriller.. Joshilyn Jackson's"Mother May I" (Morrow, 324 pages, $27.99) begins with this arresting first sentence: "I woke up to see a witch peering in my bedroom window." It's the figment of a lingering dream, decides 38-year-old Bree Cabbat, wife of lawyer Trey and mother of two teenage daughters and an infant son. But Bree soon concludes the vision was real when she sees it again in broad daylight at her daughters' school: not a literal witch, but a lurching old lady in a baggy black dress and knit cap.

title: Mega Stocks Take Back Control of Market Rally

Small, cheap, economically-sensitive stocks are good, while bonds, big, bondlike stocks and those that react strongly to interest rates are bad.

title: Hot New Fitness Product: The Outside
summary: Amid a crush of indoor fitness products, a testimonial for simply walking out the door. It's not advertised on television, it's not a heavily hyped idea from a Silicon Valley unicorn, it doesn't have a touch screen, or any kind of screen, it doesn't employ a celebrity spokesperson, it doesn't come by truck, it's not expensive, and it requires no down payment or subscription.

title: How to Write a Thank-You Email After a Job Interview
summary: Most Popular News. Some experts say the thank-you email after an interview is as important as your cover letter, so don't waste this important opportunity to finalize your pitch-especially now that you know so much about the company, the role and your interviewer. "A properly prepared thank-you email, it just sets you apart," says Paul McDonald, senior executive director at recruitment agency Robert Half. "It shows that you care and it restates your interest in the position." Most HR managers say they consider thank-you messages when deciding who to hire, but they only receive notes from nearly a quarter of applicants, according to a survey by Robert Half. So don't miss out on this chance to stand out, in a good way.

title: Can't Take a Vacation? Airport-Inspired Menswear for Eager Travelers
summary: While pandemic restrictions have grounded most jet-setters, brands like Louis Vuitton and Balmain are suddenly showing clothes inspired by travel, not with references to destinations but to the mere idea of flying...anywhere. IN JANUARY, with global travel at a crawl thanks to the pandemic, Louis Vuitton showed a clothing collection teeming with literal travel references. Overcoats and suits came with shimmering buttons in the shape of jetliners; outerwear featured detailed map prints; and models toted various forms of luggage. For the better part of a year, much of the world had been immobilized, their passports and roller-bags collecting dust. Vuitton's collection captured the cry of grounded globe-trotters everywhere: "Get me on a plane immediately!"

summary: Doctors testify that Floyd died of oxygen deprivation, as an officer knelt on his neck, while two other officers restrained his back and legs.
